newsitem.title: USA: NEC says disappointed by ITC decision.
newsitem.headline: NEC says disappointed by ITC decision.

text.p: NEC Corp and its HNSX Supercomputers Inc unit said they were disappointed that the U.S. International Trade Commission did not terminate its investigation into Cray Research Inc's claims that NEC was dumping supercomputing equipment in the United States.

"While it is difficult for a respondent to prevail at the preliminary injury phase of an antidumping case because of the extremely low threshold of proof, the evidence here clearly established that Cray's T90 supercomputer could not meet the performance requirements established by the University Corporation for Atmospheric Research," NEC said.
"Cray's failure to win the UCAR contract was thus due to serious deficiencies in the equipment offered by Cray, and not to unfair competition from NEC," NEC added in a statement.
Cray is now owned by Silicon Graphics Inc.
NEC added that it was pleased that one ITC commissioner found no reasonable indication of injury.

Earlier Wednesday the trade commission voted to continue the dumping investigation, which began after Cray filed a July 29 complaint accusing NEC of taking a $65 million loss to supply supercomputers to the Center for Atmospheric Research.
